Award.AwardTitle: Co-Evolving Genomes: The Impact of Mitochondrial Genome Instability on the Nucleus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Essentially all eukaryotic cells, including those of humans, contain multiple genomes, and key biological functions depend on the interaction between the gene products that are encoded in each of these genomes. This project will address fundamental questions about how changes in one genome within a cell can elicit compensatory changes in another to maintain basic cellular functions. This work will provide training in cutting edge molecular genetic and computational techniques to students all the way from the undergraduate to the postdoctoral level, and findings from this research will be integrated into undergraduate education through the development of a new capstone course in molecular evolution at Colorado State University.

This research project will compare species of flowering plants that exhibit enormous natural variation in the rate of evolutionary change in their mitochondrial genomes. The project will generate and analyze large datasets of gene sequences from the nuclear genomes of these species. Analysis of sequence variation within and between these species will be used to identify changes in the nuclear genome in response to the different rates of evolution in the mitochondrial genome. Findings from these comparative analyses will be complemented by performing genetic manipulations in a well-established model species to test the biochemical and physiological effects of changes in specific genes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Essentially all eukaryotic organisms divide the genetic control of their cells between the nucleus and mitochondria, with each of these cellular compartments containing its own DNA. Key cellular functions that sustain life depend on the coordinated interactions between these genomes. This research revealed that mutation rates in the mitochondrial genome can be important drivers in the evolutionary process that maintain these interactions. By investigating a set of closely related plant species that show extreme differences in their mitochondrial mutation rates, researchers showed that key parts of the nuclear genome also change rapidly in species with high mitochondrial mutation rates, apparently as a type of evolutionary response resulting from natural selection to "keep up" with the rapidly changing mitochondrial genome. The work also used hybrids and genetic modification techniques to better understand the consequences of disrupting the evolved interactions between these genomes by generating mismatch combinations of nuclear and mitochondrial genes, which is relevant to the genetic interactions found in natural populations of many plants, animals, and even humans. The research combined numerous techniques to achieve this goal, including field collections in natural populations, plant crossing experiments, genetic modifications, DNA and RNA sequencing, biochemical analyses of mitochondrial function, and modeling of molecular structures.

The research activities provided technical training in key computational and biotechnological disciplines for over 20 researchers, ranging from high school interns to postdoctoral scientists. The project also supported multiple education and outreach events, including interactions with a local community college to facilitate transitions to 4-yr research universities, development of a new undergraduate course, and international service learning workshops on computational biology.
